bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 12, 1900

div1.p: Lazear plans for Sweitzer to visit him next winter.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 12, 1900
div1.p:
I was glad
to get your two nice
letters but sorry to hear
that you had had
tonsillitis. I hope you
have completely recovered.
You must enjoy being
near that beautiful lake.

I am glad you are to
be at Annisquam instead
of Beverly. Gloucester is
an interesting place but
rather fishy.

I have thought of a
scheme for next winter.

There is a boarding house
near here which I have
just discovered. It is
kept by a German and
I believe it is very decent.
I want you to come down
and make a stay.

The ordinary hotels and
boarding houses here
are simply impossible.
They have liked gloors
Nearly all houses have
tiled floors which are
dirty and damp and
there is no glass in the
windows only iron bars.
Most rooms have only
an iron barred door
opening on a court and
no windows at all.

When it rains you have
to let it come in or shut the shutters.
and live in darkness. Most walls
are mouldy near the floors.
This is all very picturesque but not
comfortable and I had despaired
of finding any place where you
could stay. The house I speak
of I happened to see as I went
there professionally to see an officer
who stays there. It has two
stories a large garden and in general
is like a good American country
house. It is at the opposite end
of the camp from where an are
but it is close to Buena Vista
station of the RailRoad and we
are right near the next station
trains run every hour both ways.
I hope I can get off two weeks
in October and perhaps I could
get passage for you on the
transport. Think over this scheme
of mine.
